questions.text: A 55-year-old retro-positive male (CD4 count 150 cell/mm3) presents with fever, dry cough and shortness of breath for 4 days. CT findings as given below. Which of the following is TRUE regarding the causative organism?

options.label: A
options.text: Serum LDH levels are markedly decreased which favours the diagnosis

options.label: B
options.text: Diagnosis is done by detecting serum IgM levels against the LPS layer of the organism

options.label: C
options.text: sulfadiazine plus pyrimethamine is also effective in its treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Patient should be started on ATT along with pyridoxine and sputum should be tested after 2 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. sulfadiazine plus pyrimethamine is also effective in its treatment
questions.explanation:
Solution:

sulfadiazine plus pyrimethamine is also effective in its treatment The CT scan depicts diffuse ground glass opacities typical of Pneumocystis Carinii Pneumonia(PCP). A normal CT virtually excludes the diagnosis of PCP.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A:- Levels of LDH are elevated in this disease as a result of pulmonary damage, however, a normal LDH does not rule out the disease. Option B - Diagnosis is typically established in lung tissue or pulmonary secretions by methenamine silver stain, toluidine blue O stain or Giemsa stain. Option D - Cotrimoxazole is the mainstay of treatment Sulfadiazine plus pyrimethamine , an oral regimen often used for toxoplasmosis is also highly effective in its treatment.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis from the picture depicted below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Syphilitic gumma The image shows the presence of a mass with ulceration on the hard palate which could be a malignancy . However, since it is not in choice the infective process can be gumma . Aphthous ulcers don't have a mass associated. Dentigerous cysts are located mainly related to molar teeth. Leukoplakia presents as a whitish lesion on the oral cavity and is ruled out.

Extraedge:

Syphilitic gumma Gummas tend to arise on the hard palate and tongue, although very rarely they may occur on the soft palate, lower alveolus, and parotid gland. A gumma manifests initially as lor more painless swelling. There may be eventual bone destruction, palatal perforation, and oro- nasal fistula formation. Gumma manifests radiologically as ill-defined radiolucencies that may resemble malignancy. The areas of ulceration eventually heal, although the resultant scarring can, at least on the tongue, cause fissuring Aphthous ulcer Features of aphthous ulcers Small round or ovoid ulcers 2-4 mm in diameter They have an ulcer floor that is initially yellowish but assumes a grey hue as healing and epithelialization proceed. They are surrounded by an erythematous halo and some oedema. Found on non-keratinized mobile mucosa of the lips, cheeks, floor of the mouth, sulci, or ventrum of the tongue Uncommon on the keratinized mucosa of the palate or dorsum of the tongue. Dentigerous ulcer The most common location of dentigerous cysts are the Mandibular 3rd Molars and the Maxillary Canines, and they rarely involve deciduous teeth. In this picture, the location of swelling is on the hard palate. Leukoplakia Is the focal area of keratosis appears as firmly attached white patches on the mucous membranes of the oral cavity

questions.text: PEP (post-exposure prophylaxis) means taking medicine to prevent HIV after a possible exposure. PEP should be used only in emergency situations and must be started within 72 hours after recent possible exposure to HIV. Post-exposure prophylaxis of HIV is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Raltregavir + Emtricitabine + Tenofovir The preferred PEP regimen is tenofovir + emtricitabine plus raltegravir as per CDC recommendation. Zidovudine is no longer recommended in the preferred PEP regimen. The first dose should be given as soon as possible after exposure, ideally within 2 hours. The recommended duration of PEP is 28 days. As per Indian guidelines, the latest regimen is Tenofovir+ Emtricitabine + Dolutegravir

questions.text: A 35-year-old male who is newly diagnosed with HIV is started on Tenofovir Lamivudine Efavirenz. 2 weeks after starting the drug he complains that he is having vivid abnormal dreams, sleep disturbance and disturbance in mood. Which of the following drugs can cause these symptoms?

options.label: D
options.text: Any of the above can cause these symptoms

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Efavirenz EFAVIRENZ is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor Similar to zidovudine, EFAVIRENZ inhibits The activity of viral RNA-directed DNA polymerase (i.e., reverse transcriptase) The side effects of EFAVIRENZ include Rash Dysphoria Elevated liver enzymes Abnormal vivid dreams Depression Lipid abnormalities Potentially teratogenic Therefore the most likely cause for this patient's neuropsychiatric symptoms is Efavirenz . Options A and B are not associated with these findings.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient with a CD4 count of 220 cells/ul presents with easy fatiguability for 1 month. He is currently on Zidovudine+Lamivudine+emtricitabine. His Hb is found to be 9g/dl.MCV is 102 fl. The peripheral smear is shown below. Which drug is likely a causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zidovudine The peripheral smear shows oval macrocytes with anisopoikilocytosis and a hypersegmented neutrophil MCV is >100fl . All these features are suggestive of macrocytic anaemia. Anaemia is The most common hematologic abnormality In HIV-infected patients zidovudine can cause macrocytic Anemia with increased MCV as It blocks erythroid maturation prior to Its effects on Other marrow elements.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - lamivudine - side effects:- headache. diarrhoea. heartburn. difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep. depression. stuffy nose. cough. joint pain Option C - emtricitabine side effects - headache, dizziness, weakness; indigestion, stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea; sleep problems, strange dreams; rash, skin discoloration; or. changes in the shape or location of body fat (especially in your arms, legs, face, neck, breasts, and waist).

questions.text: A 51 year female who was recently started on ART presented with jaundice, nausea and hyperglycemia. ECG done is shown below. Which can be the probable causative drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atazanavir The ECG above shows a 1st-degree av block with a prolonged PR interval The normal PR interval is 0.12-.20 seconds. In this ECG the PR interval is ~0.24 seconds The PR interval is fixed and prolonged and hence suggestive of 1st degree AV block The prolonged PR interval is a side effect of Atazanavir Other side effects of Atazanavir include Hyperbilirubinemia Nausea, vomiting Hyperglycemia Fat maldistribution Rash Transaminase elevations Renal stones

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- does not cause PR prolongation Option C- does not cause PR prolongation

Extraedge:

questions.text: Which of the following is a monoclonal antibody which functions as an entry inhibitor against the HIV virus:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ibalizumab Ibalizumab is an entry inhibitor used in combination with other antiretroviral agents in patients with multidrug-resistant HIV-1 infection The exact action mechanism of Ibalizumab remains to be elucidated. Preliminary data have consistently shown that Ibalizumab induces conformational changes of The CD4 receptors and GP120 that prevent post-CD4 binding events without eliciting an immunosuppressive MHC II response

Highyeild:

Drug (Administration) Regimen Target population Clinical outcomes Anti-IgE Omalizumab (Subcutaneous) From 75 mg up to 1200 mg every 2/4 weeks Early onset asthma. Serum total IgE levels 30 < IgE s 1500 IU/mL Positive skin prick test or specific serum IgE for perennial allergens Confirmed long-term efficacy both in adults and in children, antiviral effect, prevention of seasonal exacerbations Anti-IL-5 Mepolizumab (Subcutaneous) 100 mg every 4 weeks Eosinophilic asthma ≥300 cells/μL, NP-CSWNP 5 , late-onset asthma Excellent safety profile demonstrated clinical effect, and steroid-sparing effect Benralizumab (Subcutaneous) 30 mg every 4 weeks for the first 3 doses, then every 8 weeks Eosinophilic asthma ≥300 cells/μL, NP-CSWNP 5 , late-onset asthma High affinity for IL-5 receptor and ADCC activity, eosinophils total tissue depletion, improvement of pulmonary function Reslizumab (Intravenous) 3 mg kg -1 every 4 weeks Eosinophilic asthma ≥300 cells/μL, NP-CSWNP 5 Personalized dosage and improvement of pulmonary function Anti-IL-4/ IL-13 Dupilumab (Subcutaneous) 300 mg every 4 weeks Eosinophilic asthma ≥150-300 cells/μL, aspirin-exacerbated Significant steroid-sparing effect and improvement of pulmonary

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Ustekinumab binds to the p40 subunit of interleukin (IL)-12 and IL-23 and prevents their interaction with the cell surface IL-12Rβ1 receptor. It Is used in psoriatic arthritis, IBD etc Option B- Mepolizumab is a humanized IgG1 kappa monoclonal antibody specific for interleukin 5 (IL-5) . Mepolizumab binds to IL-5 and therefore stops IL-5 from binding to its receptor on the surface of eosinophils . Used in severe eosinophilic asthma Option D- Omalizumab binds free IgE in the serum, forming trimers and hexamers . The drug binds to IgE at the same site that the high-affinity IgE receptor (Fc-epsilon-RI) binds, so IgE bound to the drug cannot bind its receptor on mast cells and basophils . It is used in the treatment of asthma.

questions.text: An intern posted in the medicine department has a needle prick injury while drawing blood for ABG. The patient is a known case of HIV. The intern is started on post-exposure prophylaxis. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding PEP in HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: It should be initiated 72 hours after exposure

options.label: B
options.text: It should be taken for 3 months

options.label: C
options.text: Regimen used in India is Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Dolutegravir

options.label: D
options.text: HIV antibody testing is to be done 3 months after exposure

questions.correct_answer: B. It should be taken for 3 months
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It should be taken for 3 months PEP should be administered within 3 days (72 hours) The preferred regimen in India currently is TLD (tenofovir lamivudine+dolutegravir) It should be preferably initiated within 2 hours of exposure It should be administered daily for a duration of 28 days HIV antibody testing is to be performed at 3 months after exposure

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A-PEP should be administered within 72 hours. Option C- Preferred regimen in India is Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Dolutegravir Option D- HIV antibody testing is to be done after 3 months.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male has come to the HIV clinic to receive immunisation. His CD4 count is 50 cells/ul. Which of the following vaccines can he receive currently?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above There are significant problems associated with vaccination In HIV infection:- Firstly, vaccination with live organisms is contraindicated In patients with severe immune suppression , as this may result In disease from attenuated organisms. Secondly, immune responses to vaccination are impaired in HIV-infected patients. If the CD4 count is below 200 cells/mm3, then immune responses to immunization are very poor. This patient has a low CD4 count of 50 cells and therefore administration of live vaccines like MMR, varicella, influenza vaccine is not advisable. Therefore it is preferable to wait until the CD4 count has increased to more than 200 cells/mm3 on ART before immunization is given, and essential if live virus vaccines are used.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A , B & C are live vaccines and cannot be used here as CD4 <200 cells/ul

questions.text: A Mantoux test is performed on an HIV patient. Reading is taken after 72 hours which shows an induration of 6mm. What is your interpretation?

options.label: D
options.text: Reading is not taken at the right time and should be taken within 24 hr of injection

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mantoux test is positive The Mantoux tuberculin skin test (TST) is one method of determining whether a person is infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The TST is performed by injecting 1 ml of tuberculin-purified protein derivative (PPD) into the inner surface of the forearm. The injection should be made with a tuberculin syringe , with the needle bevel facing upward. The TST is an intradermal injection . When placed correctly, the injection should produce a pale elevation of the skin (a wheal) 6 to 10 mm in diameter. The skin test reaction should be read between 48 and 72 hours after administration by a healthcare worker trained to read TST results Routinely >10mm is considered positive An induration of 5 or more millimetres is considered positive .

Highyeild:

People living with HIV A recent contact with a person with infectious TB disease People with chest x-ray findings suggestive of previous TB disease People with organ transplants Other immunosuppressed people (e.g., patients on prolonged therapy with corticosteroids equivalent to/greater than 15 mg per day of prednisone or those taking TNF-alpha antagonists) HIV-infected individuals with a skin test positive should receive 9 months of isoniazid + pyridoxine.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A –Mantoux test is positive as it is more than 5 mm in an HIV-positive patient Option C - Data provided is sufficient to say that the Mantoux test is positive Option D- The reading has been done at 72 hours and is done appropriately.
